head.supplied: ¶ Will. Archer Esq of ¶ ¶ Deloraine ¶ ¶ Tasmania has as an ardent investigator of the Flora of Tasmania great claims on the consideration of the Government in this instance[.] This Gentleman contri...

div.p: D63/9087, unit 749, VPRS 1189/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

To proof.
Will. Archer Esq ofDeloraineTasmania has as an ardent investigator of the Flora of Tasmania great claims on the consideration of the Government in this instance[.] This Gentleman contributed largely towards the work published under the authority of the Home Government on the plants of Tasmania
'I received the most encouraging assistance from my friend William Archer, Esq., of Cheshunt, Tasmania, who forwarded to me a beautiful series of drawings of Tasmanian Orchids, together with £100 to be expended on the Flora' (J. Hooker (1860), vol. 1. p. vii).'Cheshunt' was the name of his property near Deloraine.
and bore out of his private means a share of the expenditure for the plates of that publication. Mr Archer moreover furnished, whenever I required it, material from Tasmania for comparison and I feel thus fully justified in recommending that his request may be acceded to.
On 20 October 1863,Archer wrote to J. McCulloch: 'As a Fellow of the Linnean Society of London, and being much interested in botanical pursuits, I trust that I am not taking too great a liberty in asking you to grant me a copy of each of Dr Mueller's admirable botanical works on the plants of Victoria, — "Fragmenta Phytographiae Australiae", & "Plants indigenous to the Colony of Victoria", — both of which I believe, the special property of the Government. Of course, I shall consider myself bound, to communicate to Dr Mueller, for the benefit of your Colony, such results bearing upon its Flora as these publications may enable me to work out.' Archer's letter was referred to M on 27 October.
On 29 October,Moore directed the Government Printer to supply the works. They were sent to Archer on 3 November.
On 9 January 1864,Archer wrote again to McCulloch: 'I request that you will pardon me for having delayed so long to express to you my sense of the liberality of your Government, and your own courtesy, in acceding to my application for a copy of Dr Mueller's valuable works on the botany of Victoria' (E64/594, unit 58, VPRS 3991,Public Record Office, Victoria).
